title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond. P represents the bond price
column5: F is the face value (par value)
column6: y is the yield to maturity as a decimal
column7: and T is the time to maturity in years. Zero-coupon bonds pay no coupons and return the face value at maturity. The price is the present value of the face value discounted at the yield to maturity.

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price (Continuous)
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond using continuous compounding. P represents the bond price
column5: F is the face value
column6: y is the continuously compounded yield to maturity as a decimal
column7: T is the time to maturity
column8: and e is Euler's number. Continuous compounding is commonly used in theoretical finance and derivatives pricing.

title: Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a coupon bond. P represents the bond price
column5: C is the periodic coupon payment
column6: F is the face value
column7: y is the yield to maturity per period as a decimal
column9: and n is the total number of periods. The price is the sum of the present values of all coupon payments plus the present value of the face value at maturity.

title: Coupon Bond Price (Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the price of an annual coupon bond using the annuity formula. P represents the bond price
column5: C is the annual coupon payment
column6: y is the annual yield to maturity as a decimal
column7: n is the number of years to maturity
column8: and F is the face value. This form simplifies the calculation by using the annuity formula for the coupon stream.

title: Coupon Bond Price (Semi-Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the price of a semi-annual coupon bond. P represents the bond price
column5: C is the annual coupon payment
column6: y is the annual yield to maturity as a decimal
column7: n is the number of years to maturity
column8: and F is the face value. Most corporate bonds pay coupons semi-annually
column9: requiring adjustment to the pricing formula.

title: Bond Price Between Coupon Dates
notes: This equation calculates the bond price between coupon dates
column5: accounting for accrued interest. P represents the clean price (excluding accrued interest)
column6: C is the coupon payment
column7: y is the yield to maturity
column8: n is the number of full periods remaining
column10: and f is the fraction of the coupon period that has elapsed. The full price (dirty price) includes accrued interest.

title: Accrued Interest
equation_latex: AI = C * (Days since last coupon / Days in coupon period)
notes: This equation calculates the accrued interest on a bond between coupon dates. AI represents the accrued interest
column5: C is the coupon payment
column6: and the ratio represents the fraction of the coupon period that has elapsed. Accrued interest compensates the seller for the interest that has accumulated since the last coupon payment.

title: Dirty Price
notes: This equation expresses the relationship between dirty price and clean price. DP represents the dirty price (full price)
column5: Clean Price is the quoted price excluding accrued interest
column6: and Accrued Interest is the interest accumulated since the last coupon. Buyers pay the dirty price
column7: which is the sum of the clean price and accrued interest.

title: Yield to Maturity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to maturity for a zero-coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity as a decimal
column5: F is the face value
column6: P is the current price
column7: and T is the time to maturity. For zero-coupon bonds
column8: the YTM is simply the annualized return from holding the bond to maturity.

title: Yield to Maturity (Coupon Bond)
notes: This equation defines the yield to maturity for a coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity that equates the present value of all cash flows to the current price P. The YTM for coupon bonds must be solved numerically (e.g.
column5: using Newton-Raphson) as there is no closed-form solution.

title: Current Yield
notes: This equation calculates the current yield of a bond. CY represents the current yield
column5: C is the annual coupon payment
column6: and P is the current bond price. The current yield measures the annual income return as a percentage of price but ignores capital gains or losses from price changes and the time value of money.

title: Yield to Call (First Call)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to call for a callable bond. y_{tc} represents the yield to call
column5: P is the current price
column6: C is the coupon payment
column7: F_c is the call price
column8: and n_c is the number of periods to the first call date. YTC measures the return if the bond is called at the first call date.

title: Yield to Worst
notes: YTC_2
column6: Fixed Income - Bond Pricing
column7: This equation calculates the yield to worst for a callable bond. YTW represents the yield to worst
column8: which is the minimum of the yield to maturity and all possible yields to call dates. This conservative measure is used by investors to evaluate callable bonds.

title: Zero-Coupon Yield Curve
notes: This equation extracts the zero-coupon yield curve from zero-coupon bond prices. r_t represents the continuously compounded zero rate for maturity t
column5: P_t is the price of a zero-coupon bond maturing at time t
column6: and t is the time to maturity. The zero-coupon yield curve is the foundation for pricing all fixed income securities.

title: Par Yield
notes: This equation calculates the par yield from zero-coupon discount factors. y_par represents the par yield (coupon rate that prices the bond at par)
column5: P_T is the discount factor for maturity T
column6: and P_t are the discount factors for each coupon date. The par yield curve shows the coupon rate required for bonds to price at par.

title: Forward Rate from Spot Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis
column5: This equation calculates the forward rate from spot rates. F_{t
column6: T} represents the forward rate from time t to time T
column7: r_t and r_T are the spot rates for maturities t and T respectively. Forward rates are implied by the current term structure and represent the market's expectation of future interest rates.

title: Forward Rate (Continuous)
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis
column5: This equation calculates the continuously compounded forward rate. F_{t
column6: T} represents the forward rate from time t to time T
column7: r_t and r_T are the continuously compounded spot rates. This linear relationship simplifies many calculations in fixed income derivatives pricing.

title: Instantaneous Forward Rate
notes: This equation defines the instantaneous forward rate. f(t) represents the instantaneous forward rate for time t
column5: r(t) is the continuously compounded spot rate
column6: and dr(t)/dt is the derivative of the spot rate curve. The instantaneous forward rate is the limit of the forward rate as the time interval approaches zero.

title: Spot Rate from Forward Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis
column5: This equation calculates the spot rate from instantaneous forward rates. r_0
column6: T represents the spot rate from time 0 to T
column7: and f(t) is the instantaneous forward rate. The spot rate is the average of the forward rates
column8: which is a fundamental property of the term structure.

title: Nelson-Siegel Yield Curve
equation_latex: y(t) = beta_0 + beta_1 * (1 - e^{-t/tau})/(t/tau) + beta_2 * ((1 - e^{-t/tau})/(t/tau) - e^{-t/tau})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel parameterization of the yield curve. y(t) represents the yield at time t
column5: beta_0 is the long-term level
column6: beta_1 is the short-term component
column7: beta_2 is the medium-term hump
column8: and tau is the decay parameter. This parsimonious model captures the typical shape of yield curves.

title: Nelson-Siegel-Svensson Extension
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel-Svensson extension with an additional hump term. y(t) represents the yield at time t
column5: beta_0
column6: beta_1
column7: beta_2
column10: tau_2 are decay parameters. This extension provides more flexibility to fit complex yield curve shapes.

title: Yield Curve Steepness
notes: This equation measures the steepness of the yield curve. Slope represents the difference between the 10-year yield and the 2-year yield. A positive slope indicates an upward-sloping yield curve (normal)
column5: while a negative slope indicates an inverted yield curve
column6: often signaling economic recession.

title: Yield Curve Curvature
notes: This equation measures the curvature (hump) of the yield curve. Curvature captures the non-linearity of the yield curve shape. A positive curvature indicates a hump-shaped yield curve
column5: while negative curvature indicates a bowl-shaped curve.

title: Butterfly Spread
notes: This equation calculates the butterfly spread of the yield curve. Butterfly measures the deviation of the intermediate yield from the average of the short and long yields. It's a key measure for yield curve strategies and relative value analysis.

title: Macaulay Duration
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a bond. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration
column5: CF_t is the cash flow at time t
column6: y is the yield to maturity per period
column7: P is the bond price
column8: and n is the number of periods. Duration measures the weighted average time to receive cash flows and is a key measure of interest rate risk.

title: Macaulay Duration (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation shows that the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond equals its time to maturity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration
column5: and T is the time to maturity. Zero-coupon bonds have the maximum duration for a given maturity because all cash flow occurs at maturity.

title: Macaulay Duration (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a perpetuity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration
column5: and y is the yield per period as a decimal. The duration of a perpetuity is finite despite infinite cash flows because distant cash flows are heavily discounted.

title: Modified Duration
notes: This equation calculates the modified duration from Macaulay duration. D_mod represents the modified duration
column5: D_mac is the Macaulay duration
column6: and y is the yield to maturity per period. Modified duration directly measures the percentage price change for a 1% change in yield and is widely used for interest rate risk management.

title: Modified Duration (Approximation)
notes: This equation approximates modified duration using finite differences. D_mod represents the modified duration
column5: P is the current bond price
column6: P_- is the price when yield decreases by dy
column7: P_+ is the price when yield increases by dy
column8: and dy is a small change in yield. This numerical approximation is useful when analytical duration is unavailable.

title: Dollar Duration
notes: This equation calculates the dollar duration (also called PV01 or DV01). DD represents the dollar duration
column5: D_mod is the modified duration
column6: and P is the bond price. Dollar duration measures the absolute price change for a 1% change in yield and is used for hedging and portfolio risk management.

title: Price Value of a Basis Point
notes: This equation calculates the price value of a basis point (PV01). PV01 represents the price change for a 1 basis point (0.01%) change in yield. PV01 is a standard risk measure used in fixed income markets and is equivalent to dollar duration scaled by 0.0001.

title: Effective Duration
notes: This equation calculates the effective duration for bonds with embedded options. D_eff represents the effective duration
column5: P is the current price
column6: P_- and P_+ are the prices when yields decrease and increase by dy respectively. Effective duration accounts for the optionality by repricing the bond using an option pricing model.

title: Key Rate Duration
equation_latex: KRD_i = -(P(y + dy_i) - P(y - dy_i)) / (2 * P * dy_i)
notes: This equation calculates the key rate duration for a specific key rate. KRD_i represents the key rate duration for key rate i
column5: P is the current price
column6: and dy_i is a change in the key rate i. Key rate duration measures sensitivity to changes in specific points on the yield curve
column7: allowing for non-parallel curve shifts.

title: Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond. Conv represents convexity
column5: CF_t is the cash flow at time t
column6: y is the yield to maturity
column7: P is the bond price
column8: and n is the number of periods. Convexity measures the curvature of the price-yield relationship and provides a second-order correction to duration-based price change estimates.

title: Convexity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a zero-coupon bond. Conv represents the convexity
column5: T is the time to maturity
column6: and y is the yield to maturity. Zero-coupon bonds have the highest convexity for a given maturity because all cash flow occurs at maturity.

title: Convexity (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a perpetuity. Conv represents the convexity
column5: and y is the yield per period. Despite infinite cash flows
column6: the convexity of a perpetuity is finite due to the heavy discounting of distant cash flows.

title: Effective Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the effective convexity for bonds with embedded options. Conv_eff represents the effective convexity
column5: P is the current price
column6: P_+ and P_- are the prices when yields increase and decrease by dy respectively. Effective convexity accounts for optionality by repricing the bond.

title: Dollar Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the dollar convexity. DC represents the dollar convexity
column5: Conv is the convexity
column6: and P is the bond price. Dollar convexity measures the absolute second-order price change and is used in conjunction with dollar duration for more accurate price change estimates.

title: Price Change Approximation
notes: This equation approximates the percentage price change of a bond for a small change in yield. dP/P represents the percentage price change
column5: D_mod is the modified duration
column6: dy is the change in yield
column7: and Conv is the convexity. The duration term provides the linear approximation
column8: while the convexity term captures the curvature effect.

title: Taylor Series Expansion
notes: This is the Taylor series expansion of bond price with respect to yield. P(y + dy) is the new price
column5: P(y) is the current price
column6: P'(y) is the first derivative (related to duration)
column7: and P''(y) is the second derivative (related to convexity). Higher-order terms are typically negligible for small yield changes.

title: Bond Portfolio Duration
notes: This equation calculates the duration of a bond portfolio. D_port represents the portfolio duration
column5: w_i is the weight of bond i in the portfolio
column6: and D_i is the duration of bond i. Portfolio duration is the weighted average of individual bond durations
column7: assuming parallel yield curve shifts.

title: Bond Portfolio Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond portfolio. Conv_port represents the portfolio convexity
column5: w_i is the weight of bond i in the portfolio
column6: and Conv_i is the convexity of bond i. Portfolio convexity is the weighted average of individual bond convexities
column7: assuming parallel yield curve shifts.

title: Immunization Condition 1
notes: This is the first immunization condition for matching asset and liability durations. D_A represents the duration of assets
column5: and D_L represents the duration of liabilities. Immunization protects the portfolio value from parallel shifts in the yield curve.

title: Immunization Condition 2
notes: This is the second immunization condition. Conv_A represents the convexity of assets
column5: and Conv_L represents the convexity of liabilities. Having higher asset convexity than liability convexity provides protection against non-parallel yield curve shifts and improves portfolio performance under large rate movements.

title: Reinvestment Risk
notes: This equation calculates the reinvestment risk of a bond. R_reinv represents the reinvestment risk
column5: CF_t is the cash flow at time t
column6: y_r is the actual reinvestment rate
column7: and y is the expected reinvestment rate. Reinvestment risk arises from uncertainty about the rates at which cash flows can be reinvested.

title: Price Risk
notes: This equation calculates the price risk of a bond. R_price represents the price risk
column5: P(y + dy) is the bond price after a yield change
column6: and P(y) is the current price. Price risk arises from uncertainty about future interest rate movements and their impact on bond prices.

title: Total Bond Risk
notes: This equation calculates the total bond risk. R_total represents the total risk
column5: which is the sum of price risk and reinvestment risk. These two risks often move in opposite directions
column6: and immunization seeks to balance them.

title: Spread Duration
equation_latex: D_spread = -(P(y + dy + ds) - P(y + dy - ds)) / (2 * P * ds)
notes: This equation calculates the spread duration
column5: which measures sensitivity to credit spread changes. D_spread represents the spread duration
column6: P is the bond price
column7: y is the risk-free rate
column8: and ds is a change in the credit spread. Spread duration is important for corporate bonds and credit risk analysis.

title: Yield Beta
notes: This equation calculates the yield beta of a bond relative to a benchmark. beta represents the yield beta
column5: which measures the bond's sensitivity to yield curve movements relative to a benchmark bond. Yield beta is used for relative value analysis and portfolio construction.

title: Tracking Error
column5: Fixed Income - Bond Risk Measures
column6: This equation calculates the tracking error of a bond portfolio. TE represents the tracking error
column7: R_portfolio
column8: t is the portfolio return at time t
column10: t is the benchmark return at time t. Tracking error measures the standard deviation of excess returns and is a key risk metric for passive bond management.

title: Information Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio of a bond portfolio. IR represents the information ratio
column5: which measures risk-adjusted excess returns. The numerator is the average excess return
column6: and TE is the tracking error. Higher information ratios indicate better risk-adjusted performance relative to the benchmark.
